message.content:
<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: You can't refer to the previous and next elements directly using a foreach loop. However, you can achieve this by using an iterator explicitly.
Here's an example of how you can refer to the previous and next elements using an iterator:

Iterator<Object> iterator = col.iterator();
Object previous = null;
Object current = null;
Object next = null;

while (iterator.hasNext()) {
    previous = current;
    current = next;
    next = iterator.next();

    // Perform your search and code execution here
    if (current.equals(searchItem)) {
        // Code for previous item
        if (previous != null) {
            // Perform code on previous item
        }

        // Code for current item
        // Perform code on current item

        // Code for next item
        if (next != null) {
            // Perform code on next item
        }
    }
}
<<<explanation>>>: In this code, we use an iterator to iterate over the collection. We keep track of the previous, current, and next elements as we iterate. Inside the loop, you can perform your search and execute code on the previous, current, and next elements as needed.
